sen.j: 嵯峨本（さがぼん）とは、日本の近世初期に行われた古活字本である。
sen.e: Saga Books (Sagabon) are old movable type imprints (kokatsuji-ban) made at the beginning of the early-modern period in Japan.
sen.cmt: 古活字本 英、仏、オランダ語の文献が全て「こかつじばん」になっていましたので、読み方はそちらに従いました。
sen.e: Saga Books (Sagabon) are old movable type imprints (kokatsuji-ban) made at the beginning of the early-modern period in Japan.
Saga Books (Sagabon) are books printed using movable type at the beginning of the early-modern period of Japan.
sen.cmt: My revision is a bit 意訳 but it communicates the same information as the Japanese, I think. I have left "(kokatsuji-ban)" in the text, but is the Japanese for "movable type" necessary?

sen.j: 京都嵯峨の豪商、角倉家が本阿弥光悦らの協力を得て出版を行った。
sen.e: The Suminokura family, wealthy merchants in Saga, Kyoto, published them with the help of Koetsu HONAMI and others.
The Suminokura family, wealthy merchants in Saga, Kyoto, published them with the help of Koetsu HONAMI and others.
The Suminokura family, wealthy merchants in Saga, Kyoto, published them with the help of Koetsu HONAMI and others.

sen.j: 角倉本、光悦本ともいわれる。
sen.e: They are also called Suminokura-bon or Koetsu-bon (Koetsu Books).
They are also called Suminokura-bon or Koetsu-bon (Koetsu Books).
They are also called Suminokura-bon or Koetsu-bon (Koetsu Books).

sen.j: 16世紀末にキリシタン版や朝鮮半島を通じて活版印刷が伝わったことに刺激を受けて、日本でも次第に出版が盛んになってゆくが、その最初期のものの一つが嵯峨本である。
sen.e: Spurred by Jesuit printing (kirishitan-ban) and the introduction of movable type by way of the Korean Peninsula at the end of the 16th century, publishing books gradually became more and more widespread in Japan as well, and Sagabon were among the earliest of these.

Spurred by Jesuit printing (kirishitan-ban) and the introduction of movable type printing technology by way of the Korean Peninsula at the end of the 16th century, publishing books gradually became more and more widespread in Japan as well, and Sagabon were among the earliest of these.
sen.cmt: Added "printing technology" after "movable type" to clarify what it is.
sen.e: Spurred by Jesuit printing (kirishitan-ban) and the introduction of movable type printing technology by way of the Korean Peninsula at the end of the 16th century, publishing books gradually became more and more widespread in Japan as well, and Sagabon were among the earliest of these.

sen.j: 当時の京都には富を蓄積した商人、五山版以来の職人、読者層が存在していたことが嵯峨本が生まれた背景である。
sen.e: Behind the birth of the Sagabon lay the fact that in Kyoto at the time, there were already a merchant class with accumulated wealth, and craftsmen from the Gozanban (Five Mountains Editions) and an existing base of readers.

Behind the birth of the Sagabon lay the fact that in Kyoto at the time there was already an existing base of readers in the form of a merchant class with accumulated wealth, and craftsmen from the Gozanban (Five Mountains Editions).
sen.cmt: Reworded the sentence to make the merchant class and the craftsmen the "existing base of readers" (I think this is what the original Japanese meant to say). Also, "from the Gozanban (Five Mountains Editions) " is fairly confusing but I left it according to the research the original translator did.
sen.e: Behind the birth of the Sagabon lay the fact that in Kyoto at the time there was already an existing base of readers in the form of a merchant class with accumulated wealth, and craftsmen from the Gozanban (Five Mountains Editions).

sen.j: 藤原惺窩ら儒学者とも交友を持った角倉素庵（了以の子）が出版業を思い立ち、本阿弥光悦、俵屋宗達らの協力で出版したものが嵯峨本といわれる古活字本である。
sen.e: Soan SUMINOKURA, the son of Ryoi, and also close to Seika FUJIWARA and other Confucian scholars, set his mind on the publishing business, and published books with the help of Koetsu HONAMI, Sotatsu TAWARAYA, and others, which were the old movable type imprints called Sagabon.

Soan SUMINOKURA, the son of Ryoi, and friend of Seika FUJIWARA and other Confucian scholars, set his mind on the publishing business, and published Sagabon with the help of Koetsu HONAMI, Sotatsu TAWARAYA, and others.
sen.cmt: Replaced "and close to" with "friend of" as this makes the sentence read a little smoother and is perhaps a closer translation of 「交友」. Cut "which were the old movable type imprints called Sagabon" and replaced the earlier "books" with "Sagabon" (since there is already an explanation of it elsewhere I didn't think readers needed to be informed again)
sen.e: Soan SUMINOKURA, the son of Ryoi, and friend of Seika FUJIWARA and other Confucian scholars, set his mind on the publishing business, and published Sagabon with the help of Koetsu HONAMI, Sotatsu TAWARAYA, and others.

sen.j: 17世紀の始め（慶長・元和 (日本)期）に作られ、雲母刷の用紙を使ったり、装丁に意匠が凝らされた豪華本であった。
sen.e: They were luxurious books using paper decorated with mica and elaborate designs on the binding, published at the beginning of the 17th century (during the Keicho-Genna years (Japan))
They were luxurious books using paper decorated with mica and elaborate designs on the binding, published at the beginning of the 17th century (during the Keicho-Genna years (Japan))
They were luxurious books using paper decorated with mica and elaborate designs on the binding, published at the beginning of the 17th century (during the Keicho-Genna years (Japan))

sen.j: 内容は古典文学が主で『伊勢物語』『徒然草』『方丈記』のほか、謡曲の本が残されている。
sen.e: The contents were mainly from classic literature, and among the books still remaining are "The Tales of Ise", "Essays in Idleness", "The Ten Foot Square Hut", and some No plays.
The contents were mostly classic literature, and chief among the remaining books are The Tales of Ise, Essays in Idleness, The Ten Foot Square Hut, and some No plays.
sen.cmt: Changed "mainly from" to "mostly". Replaced "among the books still remaining" with "chief among the remaining books" (to incorperate the 「主」). Removed quotation marks from the titles.
sen.e: The contents were mostly classic literature, and chief among the remaining books are "The Tales of Ise," "Essays in Idleness," "The Ten Foot Square Hut," and some No plays.

sen.j: 嵯峨本は一文字一文字の活字を組み合わせるのではなく、光悦が書いた縦書き、崩し字の文字を数字（2-3字など）単位で木活字に作り、組み合わせて製版していた。
sen.e: The plates for Sagabon were made not by combining pieces of type one letter at a time, but by combining wooden movable type in units of several letters (2 or 3 letters, etc.) that copied the vertical and cursive style of Koetsu's writing.
sen.cmt: 崩し字 characters とすると漢字のみというニュアンスになりますが、嵯峨本は漢字かな混じり文のため、writingとしました。
sen.e: The plates for Sagabon were made not by combining pieces of type one letter at a time, but by combining wooden movable type in units of several letters of 2 or 3 that copied the vertical and cursive style of Koetsu's writing.
sen.cmt: Took "（2 or 3 letters, etc.）" out of the parenthesis as it felt a little clumsy.
sen.e: The plates for Sagabon were made not by combining pieces of type one letter at a time, but by combining wooden movable type in units of several letters of 2 or 3 that copied the vertical and cursive style of Koetsu's writing.

sen.j: 制作に手間がかかり、また繰り返し版を重ねるには木版印刷の方が容易であることから、やがて木活字は衰え、日本の印刷の歴史は活字印刷から木版印刷に逆行するような形となった。
sen.e: Because it takes time and effort to make wooden movable type and because wood block printing was easier to deal with when reprinting again and again, wooden movable type soon fell out of use and the history of printing in Japan appeared to progress backwards from wooden movable type to wood block printing.

Because it takes time and effort to make wooden movable type and because wood block printing was easier to deal with when reprinting again and again, wooden movable type soon fell out of use and the history of printing in Japan appeared to progress backwards from wooden movable type to wood block printing.
sen.cmt: I thought "appeared to progress backwards" read a bit more naturally here.
sen.e: Because it takes time and effort to make wooden movable type and because wood block printing was easier to deal with when reprinting again and again, wooden movable type soon fell out of use and the history of printing in Japan appeared to progress backwards from wooden movable type to wood block printing.
